EyeContact.question: You are talking to a friend at school.
options: A: I look at my notes and occasionally look up.
B: I mostly look down at my paper.
C: I avoid looking at them and just nod.
D: I don’t really look at them and feel out of place.
E: I look at my friend and listen carefully.

EyeContact.question: You are presenting in class.
options: A: I make eye contact with my classmates while speaking.
B: I don’t look at anyone and feel nervous.
C: I mostly look down at my paper.
D: I look at my notes and occasionally look up.
E: I only look at my friend for support.

EyeContact.question: You’re having a conversation with a teacher.
options: A: I feel uncomfortable and avoid eye contact.
B: I don’t really look at them at all.
C: I look at the teacher and nod to show I’m listening.
D: I look around the room while they talk.
E: I glance at the teacher but sometimes look at my desk.

EyeContact.question: You meet a new student.
options: A: I avoid looking at them and just nod.
B: I smile and make eye contact to welcome them.
C: I look down and don’t make eye contact.
D: I listen but often look away to avoid awkwardness.
E: I look at them but feel a bit shy.

EyeContact.question: You’re listening to a story from a friend.
options: A: I look at them most of the time but sometimes look away.
B: I look at the floor while they talk.
C: I don’t really look at them and feel out of place.
D: I get distracted and look around a lot.
E: I keep looking at my friend and show I’m interested.

EyeContact.question: You're in a job interview.
options: A: I avoid making eye contact and look at my notes.
B: I glance at the interviewer but mostly look down.
C: I make consistent eye contact to show confidence.
D: I focus on the ceiling to avoid feeling nervous.
E: I look at the interviewer but look away often.

EyeContact.question: You're at a family gathering and someone is telling a story.
options: A: I look at the storyteller and engage.
B: I occasionally glance at my phone while they talk.
C: I maintain eye contact but feel distracted.
D: I avoid eye contact and look at the ground.
E: I focus on the storyteller but feel awkward.

EyeContact.question: You're having a disagreement with a friend.
options: A: I make strong eye contact to show I'm serious.
B: I avoid eye contact because I don't want to argue.
C: I look at their face but quickly look away.
D: I make eye contact while speaking, but avoid it when they speak.
E: I make eye contact but feel uncomfortable.

EyeContact.question: You're speaking with a mentor about your career goals.
options: A: I make eye contact and feel confident.
B: I look down while they talk, feeling unsure.
C: I look at their eyes but keep looking away.
D: I glance at them occasionally, but mostly look around.
E: I avoid looking at them to focus on what I want to say.

EyeContact.question: You're in a group discussion at school.
options: A: I look at everyone in the group to engage with them.
B: I avoid looking at anyone and keep my head down.
C: I make brief eye contact with a few people.
D: I make eye contact with one person, but not the whole group.
E: I frequently look around the room to avoid focus.

EyeContact.question: You're talking to a teacher about an assignment.
options: A: I avoid making eye contact as I feel nervous.
B: I look at them in the eyes while they explain.
C: I look down at my paper to concentrate.
D: I look away while talking, but occasionally glance at them.
E: I only look at them when they ask me a question.

EyeContact.question: You're at a public speaking event.
options: A: I make eye contact with the audience to engage with them.
B: I look down at my notes to stay focused.
C: I avoid eye contact with the crowd and stare at a spot in the back.
D: I make eye contact with a few people to connect.
E: I make eye contact only with a person in the front row.

EyeContact.question: You're in a debate with a classmate.
options: A: I maintain strong eye contact to assert my point.
B: I avoid eye contact as I feel intimidated.
C: I glance at my opponent but mostly look away.
D: I keep looking at my notes but occasionally glance up.
E: I look at them but feel anxious about the debate.

EyeContact.question: You're meeting a new person at a social event.
options: A: I smile and make consistent eye contact.
B: I look around the room while talking.
C: I make brief eye contact and look away quickly.
D: I avoid eye contact and focus on my drink.
E: I look at them but feel unsure and look away often.

EyeContact.question: You're talking to a friend about a personal matter.
options: A: I make eye contact and feel at ease.
B: I glance at them but mostly look at my phone.
C: I avoid eye contact because I’m uncomfortable.
D: I look at them but feel unsure how much to look.
E: I keep looking at them but feel a bit awkward.

Behaviour.question: You see someone drop their books in the hallway.
options: A: I laugh and walk past them.
B: I help them pick up their books.
C: I pretend I didn’t see anything.
D: I feel bad but just keep walking.
E: I watch but don’t do anything.

Behaviour.question: Your friend is upset about a bad grade.
options: A: I listen but don’t say much.
B: I tell them not to worry about it.
C: I comfort them and help them study for next time.
D: I don’t talk to them at all.
E: I change the subject to something else.

Behaviour.question: You’re in a group project and someone is quiet.
options: A: I ignore them and continue working.
B: I talk to the others and forget about them.
C: I ask them for their ideas and include them.
D: I let someone else talk to them.
E: I feel annoyed that they aren’t helping.

Behaviour.question: A classmate needs help with homework.
options: A: I laugh and say it’s too easy for me.
B: I offer to help them understand it better.
C: I tell them to ask someone else.
D: I say I can’t help but feel bad.
E: I just ignore them.

Behaviour.question: You’re playing a game and someone loses.
options: A: I make a joke about it.
B: I encourage them to try again and cheer them up.
C: I ignore their feelings and celebrate my win.
D: I tell them better luck next time.
E: I just walk away from the game.

Behaviour.question: You're at a party and someone feels left out.
options: A: I join them and make them feel welcome.
B: I ignore them and keep hanging out with my friends.
C: I tell them to relax and have fun.
D: I avoid them because I don’t want to make it awkward.
E: I talk to others about how they’re feeling left out.

Behaviour.question: Your sibling accidentally breaks your favorite item.
options: A: I get really angry and yell at them.
B: I don’t say anything and just walk away.
C: I calmly explain how it upset me.
D: I laugh it off and tell them it’s okay.
E: I don’t care and don’t bring it up.

Behaviour.question: A friend invites you to their birthday, but you are busy.
options: A: I don’t go and don’t explain why.
B: I send them a gift but don’t attend.
C: I cancel my plans and go to the party.
D: I tell them I’m busy and don’t try to make it up.
E: I go to the party and try to leave early.

Behaviour.question: You hear a rumor about a friend that’s not true.
options: A: I ignore it and don’t get involved.
B: I tell others it’s not true.
C: I confront my friend and let them know what I heard.
D: I spread the rumor to others to see what happens.
E: I ask the friend directly if it’s true.

Behaviour.question: You are asked to help a group with a community project.
options: A: I ignore the request and let others do it.
B: I help and give my best effort.
C: I help but do the bare minimum.
D: I make excuses and say I’m too busy.
E: I ask others to help but don’t contribute myself.

Behaviour.question: You see someone being bullied at school.
options: A: I laugh along with the bullies.
B: I stand up for them and tell the bullies to stop.
C: I walk away because I’m scared to get involved.
D: I tell a teacher or responsible adult.
E: I ignore it and pretend I didn’t see anything.

Behaviour.question: A friend is in a bad mood, but you’re feeling happy.
options: A: I try to cheer them up and ask how I can help.
B: I ignore their mood and keep talking about how great my day was.
C: I feel awkward and don’t know what to say.
D: I try to distract them by talking about something else.
E: I leave them alone and don’t engage.

Behaviour.question: A teammate doesn’t show up for a practice session.
options: A: I tell the coach and get them in trouble.
B: I try to understand why they didn’t show up and talk to them about it.
C: I complain to others about their lack of commitment.
D: I ignore it and continue practicing alone.
E: I try to cover for them by doing extra work myself.

Behaviour.question: You see someone struggling with a heavy bag.
options: A: I walk past and ignore them.
B: I ask if they need help and offer to carry their bag.
C: I laugh at them and keep walking.
D: I offer to help but then back out.
E: I ask if they’re okay but don’t offer help.

Behaviour.question: Someone is being excluded from a conversation.
options: A: I join the conversation and exclude them too.
B: I invite them to join and make them feel included.
C: I don’t do anything and stay out of it.
D: I tell others it’s not fair they’re being excluded.
E: I feel bad for them but don’t act on it.

SocialRelationship.question: You want to make a new friend at school.
options: A: I feel nervous and avoid them.
B: I smile and say hi to them.
C: I pretend I don’t see them.
D: I keep to myself.
E: I wait for them to talk to me.

SocialRelationship.question: You see your friends chatting at lunch.
options: A: I leave the lunch area.
B: I feel left out and sit alone.
C: I listen but don’t say much.
D: I just watch and don’t participate.
E: I join in and share stories.

SocialRelationship.question: You invite a friend to hang out.
options: A: I don’t invite anyone.
B: I suggest fun activities for us to do.
C: I just text them without planning anything.
D: I feel nervous about asking.
E: I wait for them to pick something.

SocialRelationship.question: A friend is feeling down.
options: A: I ask them what’s wrong and offer support.
B: I listen but feel unsure how to help.
C: I ignore their feelings.
D: I leave them alone.
E: I change the subject to something light.

SocialRelationship.question: You see two friends arguing.
options: A: I take sides and argue back.
B: I laugh and find it funny.
C: I watch and stay quiet.
D: I walk away from the situation.
E: I try to help them talk it out.

SocialRelationship.question: You see a classmate sitting alone in the library.
options: A: I approach them and ask if they want to talk.
B: I ignore them and sit elsewhere.
C: I feel awkward and walk away.
D: I watch from a distance but don’t interact.
E: I send them a message to check on them.

SocialRelationship.question: You’re at a group gathering, and no one is talking to you.
options: A: I leave the gathering.
B: I try to start a conversation with someone.
C: I stay quiet and wait for someone to approach me.
D: I feel uncomfortable and stay by myself.
E: I look for someone to talk to but don’t approach them.

SocialRelationship.question: You’re planning a surprise party for a friend.
options: A: I organize everything and make sure it’s perfect.
B: I ask others for help but do most of the work.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t participate much.
D: I don’t plan it and let someone else take charge.
E: I suggest the idea but don’t help with the planning.

SocialRelationship.question: A friend invites you to an event but you’re not sure if you want to go.
options: A: I go because they invited me.
B: I decline the invitation politely and suggest we hang out later.
C: I ignore the invitation and don’t respond.
D: I feel uncomfortable and don’t reply.
E: I tell them I can’t make it but offer an alternative plan.

SocialRelationship.question: You and a friend have different opinions on something important.
options: A: I try to understand their perspective and discuss it calmly.
B: I insist that my opinion is correct.
C: I avoid the conversation altogether.
D: I argue and get frustrated.
E: I change the subject to avoid conflict.

SocialRelationship.question: You see a friend going through a tough time, but they’re not talking about it.
options: A: I give them space and let them open up when they’re ready.
B: I try to encourage them to talk about it.
C: I leave them alone and don’t intervene.
D: I tell them to get over it and move on.
E: I ask mutual friends to check on them instead.

SocialRelationship.question: You overhear a classmate talking negatively about you.
options: A: I confront them and ask why they said that.
B: I ignore it and focus on my own things.
C: I feel hurt but don’t say anything.
D: I tell other people about it to get support.
E: I talk to a trusted friend to get advice.

SocialRelationship.question: You’re planning to meet up with a group of friends but something comes up.
options: A: I apologize and reschedule the meeting.
B: I cancel the meeting without explaining why.
C: I don’t show up and don’t communicate.
D: I explain the situation and try to make it work later.
E: I just don’t show up and wait for them to reach out.

SocialRelationship.question: Your friend is excited about a new hobby they’ve started.
options: A: I show interest and ask them to teach me more.
B: I pretend to care but don’t show much interest.
C: I ignore their excitement and don’t engage.
D: I tell them I’m not interested in their hobby.
E: I support them but don’t get involved myself.

SocialRelationship.question: You hear a rumor about a friend being spread by others.
options: A: I defend my friend and tell people the truth.
B: I don’t get involved and ignore it.
C: I spread the rumor to others.
D: I confront my friend and ask if it’s true.
E: I tell others to stop talking about it and leave it alone.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re explaining something to a group.
options: A: I struggle to explain what I mean.
B: I rush through my words.
C: I speak clearly and use examples.
D: I mumble sometimes.
E: I just keep quiet and let others talk.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re sharing a story with friends.
options: A: I feel shy and speak quietly.
B: I give up halfway through.
C: I tell it enthusiastically and engage them.
D: I tell it but don’t add much detail.
E: I get confused and lose my train of thought.

SpeechConveyance.question: You need to ask a teacher a question.
options: A: I ask confidently and clearly.
B: I wait until someone else asks first.
C: I ask but feel embarrassed.
D: I mumble and feel nervous.
E: I don’t ask anything at all.

SpeechConveyance.question: You are in a debate at school.
options: A: I present my points clearly and confidently.
B: I feel too nervous to speak.
C: I forget my main points during the debate.
D: I stay quiet and let others debate.
E: I share my opinion but fumble my words.

SpeechConveyance.question: You need to give a presentation.
options: A: I rush through it without much thought.
B: I avoid giving the presentation altogether.
C: I practice and speak clearly to my audience.
D: I speak but feel a bit nervous.
E: I get stuck and don’t know what to say.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re introducing yourself to a new group of people.
options: A: I speak clearly and introduce myself confidently.
B: I fumble and feel awkward about my introduction.
C: I just say my name and stay quiet.
D: I rush through it and feel nervous.
E: I don’t introduce myself at all.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re giving feedback to a peer on their project.
options: A: I give specific and helpful suggestions.
B: I don’t say much because I’m unsure what to say.
C: I rush through my feedback without offering any detail.
D: I avoid giving feedback altogether.
E: I hesitate and fumble when I speak.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re telling a joke to your friends.
options: A: I tell it with confidence and everyone laughs.
B: I forget the punchline halfway through.
C: I mumble and no one understands the joke.
D: I don’t tell the joke and stay quiet.
E: I tell it but feel uncomfortable the entire time.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re giving an answer in class.
options: A: I speak confidently and explain my answer clearly.
B: I get nervous and forget what I wanted to say.
C: I speak quietly and no one can hear me.
D: I speak too fast and rush through my answer.
E: I stay quiet and don’t answer the question.

SpeechConveyance.question: You need to ask a question during a lecture.
options: A: I ask my question clearly and confidently.
B: I raise my hand but don’t ask because I’m too nervous.
C: I mumble my question and hope someone else asks it.
D: I don’t ask the question and just stay quiet.
E: I ask but I’m not sure if I said it correctly.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re explaining a difficult concept to a friend.
options: A: I explain it step by step and make sure they understand.
B: I give up explaining when they don’t understand right away.
C: I try to explain it but get lost in my words.
D: I avoid explaining it and ask someone else to do it.
E: I rush through the explanation without checking if they understand.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re sharing an idea during a brainstorming session.
options: A: I share my idea confidently and explain it well.
B: I hesitate and don’t share my idea clearly.
C: I quickly explain my idea but don’t elaborate much.
D: I stay quiet and let others share their ideas.
E: I mumble and my idea doesn’t come across well.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re presenting a group project to the class.
options: A: I present confidently and explain each part of the project clearly.
B: I get too nervous and forget some important points.
C: I speak too quickly and don’t make sense.
D: I speak clearly but feel uncomfortable the whole time.
E: I avoid speaking and let others do the talking.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re ordering food at a restaurant.
options: A: I speak clearly and confidently to place my order.
B: I mumble and the waiter asks me to repeat myself.
C: I get nervous and forget what I wanted to order.
D: I speak too softly and the waiter doesn’t hear me.
E: I avoid ordering and let someone else do it.

SpeechConveyance.question: You’re giving a toast at a family event.
options: A: I speak clearly and confidently, and everyone listens.
B: I forget what I wanted to say and start over.
C: I mumble and feel uncomfortable the whole time.
D: I rush through the toast and don’t enjoy the moment.
E: I don’t give a toast and let someone else do it.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re studying for a test.
options: A: I study but check my phone a lot.
B: I focus well and avoid distractions.
C: I get distracted easily by noise.
D: I find it hard to concentrate and daydream.
E: I don’t study and just hope for the best.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re watching a movie.
options: A: I watch but occasionally check my messages.
B: I get bored and start thinking about other things.
C: I keep talking and miss important parts.
D: I pay full attention and enjoy it.
E: I just watch others play instead.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re doing homework.
options: A: I stay focused and finish my work quickly.
B: I work but keep getting distracted by friends.
C: I struggle to concentrate and take long breaks.
D: I often stop and lose track of what I’m doing.
E: I don’t do my homework and forget about it.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re listening to a teacher in class.
options: A: I pay attention and take good notes.
B: I listen but occasionally zone out.
C: I find it hard to focus and get distracted.
D: I ignore the lesson and think about other things.
E: I often talk to friends instead of listening.

ConcentrationLevel.question: You’re playing a video game.
options: A: I get frustrated and stop playing.
B: I concentrate and try to win the game.
C: I play but sometimes get distracted by chats.
D: I lose focus and miss important moves.
E: I just watch others play instead.

SelfRegulation.question: You feel angry about a disagreement.
options: A: I ignore my feelings and don’t talk to anyone.
B: I express my feelings but try not to yell.
C: I walk away but stay angry inside.
D: I get upset and say things I don’t mean.
E: I take a deep breath and talk it out calmly.

SelfRegulation.question: You want to eat healthier snacks.
options: A: I forget about healthy snacks and only eat sweets.
B: I choose fruits or vegetables instead of junk food.
C: I try to limit junk food but sometimes give in.
D: I don’t care about healthy eating.
E: I eat whatever I want without thinking.

SelfRegulation.question: You’re feeling overwhelmed with schoolwork.
options: A: I procrastinate and avoid my work.
B: I make a plan and tackle one thing at a time.
C: I start but feel lost and don’t know where to begin.
D: I ignore my workload and do something else.
E: I get stressed and feel like giving up.

SelfRegulation.question: You want to improve your grades.
options: A: I don’t take my studies seriously and hope for luck.
B: I set goals and study regularly to achieve them.
C: I try to study but don’t stick to my plan.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know how to start.
E: I don’t care about my grades.

SelfRegulation.question: You have a deadline for a project.
options: A: I forget about it until it’s too late.
B: I work on it but leave things for the last minute.
C: I get distracted and don’t make much progress.
D: I panic as the deadline approaches.
E: I start early and stay on track to finish.

SelfRegulation.question: You feel nervous before an important presentation.
options: A: I avoid thinking about it and hope it goes away.
B: I take deep breaths to calm myself down.
C: I stay anxious and let my nerves take over.
D: I practice and prepare to gain confidence.
E: I panic and worry about everything going wrong.

SelfRegulation.question: You get a low score on an exam.
options: A: I ignore it and don’t try to improve.
B: I reflect on my mistakes and work on improving.
C: I get upset and think I’ll never do well.
D: I make excuses and blame external factors.
E: I accept it and move on without making changes.

SelfRegulation.question: You feel stressed about a big event coming up.
options: A: I procrastinate and push it out of my mind.
B: I plan ahead and take it step by step.
C: I worry about everything and feel paralyzed.
D: I ignore the stress and distract myself.
E: I talk to someone to help manage my stress.

SelfRegulation.question: You’ve been given a big responsibility at school or work.
options: A: I ignore it and hope it resolves itself.
B: I break it down into smaller tasks and start early.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know where to begin.
D: I delay starting and feel stressed later.
E: I ask for help but don’t take any action myself.

SelfRegulation.question: You’re tempted to spend money on something unnecessary.
options: A: I buy it without thinking about the consequences.
B: I think about my budget and decide it’s not worth it.
C: I feel guilty but buy it anyway.
D: I talk myself into buying it by convincing myself I deserve it.
E: I resist the temptation and save my money.

SelfRegulation.question: You’re tempted to skip a workout you promised yourself to do.
options: A: I skip the workout and promise to do it tomorrow.
B: I remind myself of my goals and go ahead with the workout.
C: I feel lazy and give up on my plan.
D: I make excuses and avoid doing it.
E: I reschedule the workout and stick to the new plan.

SelfRegulation.question: You’re feeling frustrated with a difficult task.
options: A: I give up and leave it unfinished.
B: I take a break and return to it with a clear mind.
C: I get more frustrated and keep trying without a plan.
D: I distract myself with something else.
E: I step away for a while and try a new approach later.

SelfRegulation.question: You’re tempted to gossip about someone.
options: A: I join in with the gossip.
B: I refuse to participate and redirect the conversation.
C: I feel conflicted but stay quiet.
D: I tell myself it’s harmless and go along with it.
E: I step away from the conversation and avoid getting involved.

SelfRegulation.question: You receive constructive criticism from a teacher or boss.
options: A: I get defensive and argue with them.
B: I listen carefully and try to learn from it.
C: I feel bad but don’t say anything.
D: I avoid them after receiving feedback.
E: I take it personally and let it affect my mood.

SelfRegulation.question: You feel like you are losing focus during a study session.
options: A: I keep studying and push through without breaks.
B: I take short breaks to regain focus and come back stronger.
C: I get distracted and don’t focus on studying anymore.
D: I quit and decide to study later.
E: I get frustrated and stop working.

StressLevel.question: You have a big test coming up.
options: A: I ignore the test and do other things.
B: I study and manage my time well.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t study at all.
D: I worry a lot and can’t focus on studying.
E: I feel a little stressed but try to prepare.

StressLevel.question: You’re in a busy class with lots of noise.
options: A: I get annoyed and can’t pay attention.
B: I find a way to concentrate despite the noise.
C: I leave the classroom to get some quiet.
D: I just give up on trying to listen.
E: I feel distracted but try to focus.

StressLevel.question: You’re handling a group project with tight deadlines.
options: A: I stay organized and communicate with my team.
B: I argue with my group because of stress.
C: I struggle to keep up and feel stressed.
D: I withdraw and let others handle it.
E: I manage but feel some pressure.

StressLevel.question: You have too many extracurricular activities.
options: A: I feel overwhelmed and want to quit.
B: I balance my time and enjoy my activities.
C: I get stressed and sometimes miss things.
D: I don’t participate in anything anymore.
E: I feel a little overwhelmed but keep going.

StressLevel.question: You have family or friend issues.
options: A: I avoid talking about it.
B: I get upset and react negatively.
C: I ignore it and pretend it’s not there.
D: I talk to someone about how I feel.
E: I keep my feelings to myself but feel stressed.

StressLevel.question: You’re getting ready for a final presentation.
options: A: I panic and can’t focus on my work.
B: I prepare early and rehearse my presentation.
C: I leave it until the last minute and rush to prepare.
D: I procrastinate and get stressed later.
E: I feel anxious but manage to stay on track.

StressLevel.question: You have multiple assignments due the same week.
options: A: I ignore them and hope they’ll go away.
B: I stay organized and prioritize tasks to manage them.
C: I feel stressed and struggle to finish them on time.
D: I get overwhelmed and don’t know where to start.
E: I feel a little stressed but keep working on them.

StressLevel.question: You have to give a speech in front of a large audience.
options: A: I get really nervous and freeze.
B: I practice a lot and feel prepared.
C: I procrastinate and get stressed the night before.
D: I feel anxious but try to stay calm.
E: I avoid the situation altogether.

StressLevel.question: You’re in a stressful situation with a friend.
options: A: I avoid dealing with the issue and pretend everything is fine.
B: I try to talk it out and resolve the conflict.
C: I get upset and don’t handle it well.
D: I withdraw and let things be.
E: I try to stay calm but feel stressed inside.

StressLevel.question: You have to make a difficult decision.
options: A: I avoid making the decision and let others decide for me.
B: I take my time and weigh my options carefully.
C: I feel stressed and rush to make a choice.
D: I try to avoid thinking about it altogether.
E: I take a deep breath and make a decision with confidence.

StressLevel.question: You’re feeling overwhelmed with all the tasks you need to complete.
options: A: I ignore everything and procrastinate.
B: I make a list and tackle one task at a time.
C: I panic and don’t know where to begin.
D: I get frustrated and give up.
E: I take small breaks to manage the stress.

StressLevel.question: You’re in a group project, but one member isn’t contributing.
options: A: I ignore it and let the others do all the work.
B: I discuss it with the group and try to come to a solution.
C: I get frustrated and complain to others about the member.
D: I try to do everything myself and feel stressed.
E: I keep quiet but feel stressed about the situation.

StressLevel.question: You’re preparing for a test and feel stressed about it.
options: A: I cram all night and hope I remember everything.
B: I take breaks, stay organized, and study consistently.
C: I get distracted and can’t concentrate.
D: I give up studying and feel anxious.
E: I try to relax but feel stressed anyway.

StressLevel.question: You’re dealing with a situation where things are not going as planned.
options: A: I feel helpless and just give up.
B: I adapt and try to find a new solution.
C: I get frustrated and keep trying the same thing.
D: I panic and get stressed about the consequences.
E: I stay calm and focus on what I can control.

StressLevel.question: You feel pressure to meet a deadline for a project.
options: A: I procrastinate and leave it until the last minute.
B: I stay focused and make steady progress.
C: I feel overwhelmed and can’t concentrate.
D: I start the project but get sidetracked easily.
E: I stay organized and finish ahead of time.

BodyMind.question: You’re playing a sport like basketball.
options: A: I often get confused about where to go.
B: I move quickly and keep my eyes on the ball.
C: I try to keep up, but I stumble sometimes.
D: I struggle to follow the game and feel out of place.
E: I prefer to watch rather than play.

BodyMind.question: You’re learning a dance routine.
options: A: I get some moves right but mess up a few.
B: I feel clumsy and don’t enjoy it.
C: I don’t want to participate at all.
D: I practice and can follow the steps easily.
E: I find it hard to remember the steps.

BodyMind.question: You’re drawing or painting.
options: A: I focus and create what I imagine.
B: I try, but my lines aren’t very steady.
C: I get frustrated and give up easily.
D: I feel I can’t express what I want to create.
E: I don’t draw because I think I’m not good at it.

BodyMind.question: You’re playing a video game that requires quick reactions.
options: A: I react fast and enjoy the challenge.
B: I do okay but miss some important moves.
C: I often take too long to respond.
D: I feel overwhelmed and can’t keep up.
E: I watch others play instead of participating.

BodyMind.question: You’re practicing a new instrument.
options: A: I can play the notes and enjoy it.
B: I don’t want to practice.
C: I struggle but keep trying.
D: I find it difficult and often get frustrated.
E: I feel like I’m not improving at all.

BodyMind.question: You’re running a race.
options: A: I get tired quickly and struggle to keep up.
B: I pace myself and finish strong.
C: I lose focus and get distracted by other runners.
D: I feel like I can’t finish and slow down.
E: I walk instead of running.

BodyMind.question: You’re cooking a complicated recipe.
options: A: I follow the steps carefully and everything turns out great.
B: I forget some steps but still make it work.
C: I get confused by the instructions and feel frustrated.
D: I lose track of what I’m doing and make a mess.
E: I let someone else cook for me.

BodyMind.question: You’re trying to do a complicated yoga pose.
options: A: I can hold the pose with ease and feel relaxed.
B: I struggle but eventually get the form right.
C: I fall out of the pose and feel frustrated.
D: I can’t get the pose right no matter how hard I try.
E: I skip the pose and move to something easier.

BodyMind.question: You’re riding a bike on a busy street.
options: A: I stay alert and handle the traffic well.
B: I feel nervous but manage to get through.
C: I get distracted and almost miss turns.
D: I feel overwhelmed and pull over.
E: I avoid busy streets and stay on quieter paths.

BodyMind.question: You’re preparing for a stage performance.
options: A: I focus well and perform with confidence.
B: I get nervous but still manage to perform.
C: I forget my lines or steps and feel embarrassed.
D: I struggle with my performance and can’t get it right.
E: I back out and let others perform instead.

BodyMind.question: You’re learning a new sport.
options: A: I pick up the skills quickly and enjoy the sport.
B: I struggle but keep practicing and improving.
C: I find it hard to keep up and get frustrated.
D: I don’t feel motivated and stop practicing.
E: I prefer to watch others play rather than participate.

BodyMind.question: You’re setting up a new piece of furniture.
options: A: I follow the instructions carefully and set it up easily.
B: I get confused by the instructions but figure it out.
C: I struggle and need help to complete it.
D: I get frustrated and stop working on it.
E: I hire someone else to set it up for me.

BodyMind.question: You’re doing a puzzle that requires pattern recognition.
options: A: I complete the puzzle quickly with ease.
B: I take my time but eventually solve it.
C: I get frustrated and can’t find the pieces.
D: I lose focus and stop working on the puzzle.
E: I ask for help to finish the puzzle.

BodyMind.question: You’re writing a long essay or paper.
options: A: I stay focused and write with ease.
B: I write but get distracted and need to refocus.
C: I get stuck and don’t know what to write next.
D: I lose track of time and struggle to finish on time.
E: I give up and don’t finish the essay.

BodyMind.question: You’re trying to juggle multiple tasks at once.
options: A: I manage everything efficiently and stay on top of tasks.
B: I multitask but get distracted and fall behind.
C: I get overwhelmed and can’t handle everything.
D: I ignore some tasks to focus on others.
E: I prioritize only a few tasks and let others go.

Empathy.question: A friend is feeling sad.
options: A: I laugh and make jokes.
B: I tell them it will be okay but don’t listen much.
C: I listen and try to understand their feelings.
D: I change the subject to something happier.
E: I don’t acknowledge their sadness.

Empathy.question: You see a classmate being bullied.
options: A: I feel uncomfortable and just stay quiet.
B: I watch and feel bad but don’t intervene.
C: I stand up for them and help them feel better.
D: I ignore the situation and walk away.
E: I laugh along and don’t say anything.

Empathy.question: Your sibling has a bad day at school.
options: A: I ask them what happened and listen.
B: I tell them to get over it.
C: I laugh and say it’s not a big deal.
D: I try to cheer them up but don’t ask details.
E: I ignore them because I’m busy.

Empathy.question: You see someone upset in public.
options: A: I think they just need to toughen up.
B: I feel bad but keep walking.
C: I check if they’re okay and ask if they need help.
D: I ignore them and look away.
E: I don’t care about what they’re going through.

Empathy.question: A friend shares a personal story.
options: A: I don’t pay attention and just nod.
B: I cut them off and share my own story.
C: I listen closely and show I care.
D: I act disinterested and change the topic.
E: I listen but think about other things.

Empathy.question: A friend is going through a tough breakup.
options: A: I tell them to move on and stop worrying.
B: I comfort them but don’t really listen.
C: I listen to their feelings and offer support.
D: I tell them it’s not a big deal and try to change the subject.
E: I ignore their feelings because I’m busy.

Empathy.question: You see someone struggling with their work in class.
options: A: I don’t offer help and let them figure it out.
B: I offer to help them but don’t explain much.
C: I ask if they need help and assist them with their task.
D: I make fun of their struggle to lighten the mood.
E: I ignore them and focus on my own work.

Empathy.question: You see a classmate working hard on a project.
options: A: I congratulate them but don’t ask about their progress.
B: I ignore them and focus on my own work.
C: I offer to help or give them some encouragement.
D: I make a joke about how hard they’re working.
E: I don’t care and don’t acknowledge their effort.

Empathy.question: A friend is feeling sick and has to cancel plans.
options: A: I get annoyed and tell them it’s not a big deal.
B: I tell them to rest but don’t offer further help.
C: I express concern and offer to help them feel better.
D: I ignore it and don’t ask how they’re doing.
E: I make them feel guilty about canceling.

Empathy.question: You see a colleague upset about missing a deadline.
options: A: I tell them they should have been more organized.
B: I ignore them and continue with my work.
C: I listen to their concerns and offer help if I can.
D: I laugh it off and tell them not to worry.
E: I feel sorry for them but don’t offer anything.

Empathy.question: You see a friend trying hard to fit in.
options: A: I ignore their efforts and mind my own business.
B: I try to get closer to them and help them feel accepted.
C: I make fun of them for trying so hard.
D: I feel bad for them but don’t know how to help.
E: I encourage them to keep being themselves.

Empathy.question: A friend is upset about not getting a job they wanted.
options: A: I tell them they should’ve tried harder.
B: I sympathize but don’t know what to say.
C: I offer emotional support and suggest next steps.
D: I tell them it’s no big deal and they’ll get over it.
E: I avoid talking about it because I don’t know how to help.

Empathy.question: You overhear someone talking about their personal issues.
options: A: I ignore it and pretend I didn’t hear anything.
B: I feel awkward and change the subject.
C: I offer them a chance to talk if they want.
D: I gossip about it with others.
E: I tell them they should get over it.

Empathy.question: You’re walking in the hall and see someone drop their books.
options: A: I laugh and keep walking.
B: I stop and help them pick it up.
C: I ignore it and continue my walk.
D: I quickly help them but feel annoyed.
E: I offer them a quick glance and move on.

Empathy.question: A friend shares their struggles with you.
options: A: I tell them to get over it and move on.
B: I listen but don’t offer any advice.
C: I empathize with their feelings and offer solutions.
D: I try to cheer them up but don’t listen to what they’re saying.
E: I feel bad for them but don’t say anything.

Motivation.question: You set a goal to get fit.
options: A: I try to exercise but miss some days.
B: I create a workout plan and stick to it.
C: I feel like it’s too hard and want to quit.
D: I don’t care about getting fit.
E: I don’t really keep track of my progress.

Motivation.question: You want to learn a new language.
options: A: I practice a little every day.
B: I don’t believe I can learn it.
C: I study sometimes but often forget.
D: I think about it but never start.
E: I find it too challenging and give up.

Motivation.question: You want to improve your grades.
options: A: I set study goals and ask for help when needed.
B: I study occasionally but don’t stick to a plan.
C: I don’t care much about school.
D: I do my homework but don’t study much.
E: I feel stressed and don’t know where to begin.

Motivation.question: You’re working on a personal project.
options: A: I start with excitement but lose interest quickly.
B: I think about it but never take action.
C: I don’t feel motivated to do anything.
D: I get overwhelmed and stop trying.
E: I plan it out and work on it regularly.

Motivation.question: You want to help out in your community.
options: A: I don’t see the point in volunteering.
B: I want to help but feel too busy.
C: I think about it but don’t sign up.
D: I find a way to volunteer and participate actively.
E: I don’t follow through with my intentions.

Motivation.question: You want to save money for something big.
options: A: I start saving but spend some of the money along the way.
B: I create a budget and stick to it consistently.
C: I forget about my goal and spend impulsively.
D: I don’t care much about saving.
E: I don’t track my savings or progress.

Motivation.question: You want to wake up earlier each day.
options: A: I try to wake up earlier but often press snooze.
B: I make a habit of waking up earlier and feel more productive.
C: I struggle to wake up earlier and feel groggy.
D: I don’t see the point in waking up early.
E: I don’t stick to a consistent wake-up time.

Motivation.question: You want to eat healthier.
options: A: I try to eat healthy but sometimes give in to cravings.
B: I stick to a balanced diet and avoid junk food.
C: I feel too lazy to make healthy meals.
D: I don’t care about eating healthy.
E: I don’t pay attention to what I eat.

Motivation.question: You want to improve your social skills.
options: A: I try to engage more with others but don’t practice consistently.
B: I join social events and actively work on my communication.
C: I find it hard to talk to others and stay quiet.
D: I don’t think I need to work on my social skills.
E: I avoid socializing whenever I can.

Motivation.question: You want to read more books.
options: A: I read occasionally but often get distracted.
B: I make time to read and finish books regularly.
C: I feel too busy to read and don’t make time for it.
D: I don’t enjoy reading as much as other activities.
E: I don’t set reading goals or track my progress.

Motivation.question: You want to be more organized in your daily life.
options: A: I make to-do lists but don’t follow through.
B: I create systems and stick to them to stay organized.
C: I get overwhelmed by organizing and avoid it.
D: I don’t prioritize organization.
E: I try to organize but often forget.

Motivation.question: You want to improve your public speaking skills.
options: A: I avoid public speaking because it makes me nervous.
B: I practice and participate in public speaking when possible.
C: I sometimes speak in front of others but lack confidence.
D: I don’t think public speaking is important.
E: I get overwhelmed and avoid speaking in public.

Motivation.question: You want to get better at time management.
options: A: I try to plan my day but don’t follow through.
B: I prioritize tasks and manage my time effectively.
C: I get distracted and often waste time.
D: I don’t plan my day at all.
E: I try to manage my time but get overwhelmed.

Motivation.question: You want to reduce procrastination.
options: A: I try to get started but end up delaying things.
B: I set small goals and start tasks right away.
C: I keep putting things off and feel guilty.
D: I don’t make an effort to stop procrastinating.
E: I try to avoid procrastination but don’t succeed.

Motivation.question: You want to develop a new habit, like waking up early.
options: A: I try to wake up early but often sleep in.
B: I consistently wake up early and feel more productive.
C: I don’t make any effort to wake up early.
D: I feel too tired to wake up early and don’t make it a priority.
E: I give up trying to wake up early after a few days.

SelfAwareness.question: You realize you’re feeling stressed.
options: A: I feel confused about my emotions.
B: I take a moment to understand why I feel this way.
C: I ignore my feelings and keep going.
D: I know I’m stressed but don’t think about it.
E: I just brush it off and don’t reflect.

SelfAwareness.question: You notice you’re upset about something.
options: A: I struggle to understand my feelings.
B: I think about what made me feel this way.
C: I distract myself instead of facing it.
D: I know I’m upset but don’t explore it further.
E: I don’t acknowledge my emotions.

SelfAwareness.question: You reflect on how you did in a competition.
options: A: I forget about it and move on quickly.
B: I feel okay about it but don’t dwell on it.
C: I analyze my performance and think about improvements.
D: I don’t care about my results.
E: I feel disappointed but don’t understand why.

SelfAwareness.question: You recognize your strengths and weaknesses.
options: A: I can list what I’m good at and what I need to work on.
B: I don’t think about it at all.
C: I feel unsure about what I’m good at.
D: I focus on my weaknesses and ignore my strengths.
E: I know I have strengths but struggle to see weaknesses.

SelfAwareness.question: You feel nervous before a presentation.
options: A: I just avoid presenting altogether.
B: I acknowledge my nerves and prepare myself.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know what to do.
D: I pretend I’m not nervous but feel anxious inside.
E: I know I’m nervous but try to ignore it.

SelfAwareness.question: You realize you’re feeling overwhelmed by your responsibilities.
options: A: I try to ignore the feeling and continue with my tasks.
B: I recognize that I’m overwhelmed and try to figure out why.
C: I feel confused about why I feel this way and ignore it.
D: I know I’m overwhelmed but don’t think about how to manage it.
E: I push through the stress without reflecting on it.

SelfAwareness.question: You notice you’re feeling irritated during a conversation.
options: A: I don’t recognize why I’m irritated.
B: I acknowledge my irritation and try to understand its cause.
C: I ignore my feelings and keep talking.
D: I know I’m irritated but don’t think about it.
E: I try to brush off the irritation without reflection.

SelfAwareness.question: You’re dealing with a mistake you made at work/school.
options: A: I feel ashamed but don’t reflect on how to avoid it next time.
B: I quickly forget about it and move on.
C: I analyze the situation to learn from my mistake.
D: I get upset but don’t understand why I made the mistake.
E: I try to blame someone else for the mistake.

SelfAwareness.question: You’re feeling proud of an accomplishment.
options: A: I take a moment to appreciate my effort and success.
B: I feel good about it but don’t reflect on why I’m proud.
C: I quickly move on to the next task without acknowledging my pride.
D: I don’t think much about it and just continue with my day.
E: I feel happy but don’t understand what I did well.

SelfAwareness.question: You realize you’re feeling tired and unmotivated.
options: A: I just keep pushing through without acknowledging how I feel.
B: I recognize my fatigue and try to understand why I’m unmotivated.
C: I ignore the feeling and keep working.
D: I know I’m tired but don’t reflect on my energy levels.
E: I ignore my tiredness and push myself harder.

SelfAwareness.question: You notice you’re feeling jealous of someone.
options: A: I don’t think about why I’m jealous and just feel it.
B: I acknowledge my jealousy and try to understand the cause.
C: I ignore the feeling and don’t analyze it.
D: I feel jealous but don’t explore the underlying reasons.
E: I try to avoid acknowledging my jealousy.

SelfAwareness.question: You realize you’re feeling anxious about an upcoming event.
options: A: I acknowledge my anxiety and reflect on why I feel this way.
B: I ignore my anxiety and focus on other things.
C: I avoid thinking about the event altogether.
D: I feel anxious but don’t explore the reason behind it.
E: I try to suppress my anxiety and push through.

SelfAwareness.question: You notice you’re feeling unappreciated at work/school.
options: A: I ignore the feeling and don’t reflect on it.
B: I acknowledge how I feel and try to understand why I feel unappreciated.
C: I avoid thinking about it because it feels uncomfortable.
D: I know I feel unappreciated but don’t consider how to address it.
E: I just suppress my feelings and keep going.

SelfAwareness.question: You realize you're feeling proud of how you handled a difficult situation.
options: A: I briefly acknowledge it and move on.
B: I reflect on my strengths and feel good about my actions.
C: I don’t really think about it, just keep going.
D: I feel proud but don’t know what I did right.
E: I feel proud but don’t take the time to reflect on it.

SelfAwareness.question: You notice you’re feeling disconnected from your friends.
options: A: I ignore the feeling and continue with my day.
B: I acknowledge my disconnection and think about why I feel this way.
C: I avoid thinking about it and distract myself.
D: I know I’m disconnected but don’t explore the reason.
E: I don’t pay attention to my feelings of disconnection.

Mindfulness.question: You’re feeling overwhelmed by your thoughts.
options: A: I let my thoughts distract me.
B: I try to clear my mind but find it hard.
C: I take a moment to breathe and focus on the present.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know how to calm down.
E: I ignore my feelings and keep going.

Mindfulness.question: You’re having lunch with friends.
options: A: I focus on my meal and enjoy our conversation.
B: I just eat without thinking about it.
C: I eat while scrolling on my phone.
D: I feel distracted by everything around me.
E: I don’t pay attention to what I’m eating.

Mindfulness.question: You’re taking a walk outside.
options: A: I notice the sights and sounds around me.
B: I feel bored and want to be somewhere else.
C: I rush through without appreciating it.
D: I’m lost in thought and don’t notice anything.
E: I walk but think about other things.

Mindfulness.question: You’re doing homework.
options: A: I get distracted by my phone or TV.
B: I concentrate fully and focus on my tasks.
C: I feel overwhelmed and can’t focus.
D: I rush through my work without thinking.
E: I often daydream while working.

Mindfulness.question: You’re having a tough day.
options: A: I take a moment to reflect on my feelings.
B: I push my feelings aside and keep going.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know what to do.
D: I ignore how I feel and don’t think about it.
E: I just want to escape my thoughts.

Mindfulness.question: You’re reading a book.
options: A: I rush through the pages without absorbing the content.
B: I focus on each page and enjoy the story.
C: I get distracted and forget what I just read.
D: I feel like reading but don’t really pay attention.
E: I skim through the book while thinking about other things.

Mindfulness.question: You’re listening to music.
options: A: I get lost in the music and fully appreciate it.
B: I just listen without paying much attention to the details.
C: I listen to music while doing something else.
D: I’m distracted by my thoughts while the music plays.
E: I don’t really focus on the music at all.

Mindfulness.question: You’re talking to someone.
options: A: I listen attentively and try to understand their feelings.
B: I listen but get distracted by my own thoughts.
C: I think about what I want to say next rather than listening.
D: I only half-listen and check my phone.
E: I don’t really pay attention and don’t think about what they’re saying.

Mindfulness.question: You’re exercising at the gym.
options: A: I focus on my movements and stay aware of my body.
B: I focus on my workout but get distracted by my thoughts.
C: I work out while thinking about everything except the exercise.
D: I rush through the workout and don’t focus on form.
E: I don’t really pay attention to how I’m working out.

Mindfulness.question: You’re having a conversation with a friend who is upset.
options: A: I give them my full attention and try to understand their feelings.
B: I listen but think about what I want to say next.
C: I listen but feel distracted by other things around me.
D: I nod and say things without really thinking.
E: I don’t focus on what they’re saying and just zone out.

Mindfulness.question: You’re going through your daily routine.
options: A: I am fully aware of each task I’m doing and enjoy the process.
B: I complete my tasks but feel like I’m on autopilot.
C: I feel disconnected from what I’m doing and just go through the motions.
D: I rush through tasks without paying attention to them.
E: I don’t think about what I’m doing and just move from one thing to another.

Mindfulness.question: You’re cooking dinner.
options: A: I focus on each step and enjoy the process of cooking.
B: I cook but get distracted and forget some steps.
C: I rush through cooking and don’t pay attention to the details.
D: I think about other things while cooking.
E: I don’t really pay attention to the cooking and just follow the recipe.

Mindfulness.question: You’re traveling somewhere new.
options: A: I take in the new sights, sounds, and experiences around me.
B: I’m aware of my surroundings but think about other things.
C: I get distracted and don’t fully appreciate the place.
D: I focus on my phone and don’t notice much around me.
E: I don’t really pay attention to where I am or the experience.

Mindfulness.question: You’re doing a task you don’t enjoy.
options: A: I focus on the task and try to make the best of it.
B: I think about how much I dislike the task while doing it.
C: I rush through it and try to finish as quickly as possible.
D: I feel frustrated and distracted the whole time.
E: I try to avoid the task and think about something else.

Mindfulness.question: You’re spending time alone.
options: A: I enjoy the time and reflect on my thoughts.
B: I feel bored and think about what I should be doing.
C: I find it hard to focus on anything and feel distracted.
D: I feel uncomfortable and try to avoid being alone.
E: I don’t pay attention to my thoughts or feelings.

Creativity.question: You face a challenge at school.
options: A: I think it’s too hard and give up.
B: I believe I can overcome it with some effort.
C: I feel defeated and doubt I can succeed.
D: I hope things will improve without effort.
E: I just ignore the problem.

Creativity.question: You feel down about something.
options: A: I think things will never get better.
B: I try to find a way to feel better.
C: I believe things will improve soon.
D: I focus on the negative and feel hopeless.
E: I ignore my feelings and keep going.

Creativity.question: You face a tough situation at home.
options: A: I believe things will get worse.
B: I find ways to stay positive.
C: I feel like I can’t do anything to fix it.
D: I wait for things to get better by themselves.
E: I try to make the best of it.

Creativity.question: You think about your future.
options: A: I feel uncertain and unsure.
B: I believe good things will happen.
C: I am excited but worry about the challenges.
D: I’m not hopeful about my future.
E: I think about the difficulties ahead.

Creativity.question: You’re looking forward to a new opportunity.
options: A: I’m excited and confident.
B: I feel unsure but hopeful.
C: I’m not sure if it will work out.
D: I’m doubtful and think it might not succeed.
E: I’m afraid of failing.

Creativity.question: You encounter a difficult project at school.
options: A: I feel like I can’t handle it and give up.
B: I try different approaches until something works.
C: I procrastinate and hope someone will help me.
D: I don’t know how to approach it and feel lost.
E: I stick to the easiest method without thinking outside the box.

Creativity.question: You’re trying to solve a problem at work/school.
options: A: I struggle and get frustrated, unsure of how to solve it.
B: I brainstorm multiple solutions and test different ideas.
C: I just follow the usual solution without thinking of alternatives.
D: I ask others for help instead of trying to solve it myself.
E: I ignore the problem and hope it will resolve itself.

Creativity.question: You have to come up with a creative idea for a project.
options: A: I quickly come up with a simple idea without much effort.
B: I take time to think, research, and explore innovative ideas.
C: I copy an idea from someone else because I can’t think of anything new.
D: I get stuck and struggle to come up with anything original.
E: I settle for an average idea because it seems easy.

Creativity.question: You’re facing a setback in an important task.
options: A: I get discouraged and stop trying.
B: I think of new ways to approach the challenge and keep going.
C: I keep doing the same thing without changing my strategy.
D: I give up and wait for a solution to come on its own.
E: I focus on the problem instead of finding ways to solve it.

Creativity.question: You’re learning something new.
options: A: I get frustrated because it feels too hard.
B: I enjoy the challenge and look for creative ways to understand it.
C: I follow the instructions step-by-step without thinking about alternatives.
D: I get distracted and forget to focus on learning.
E: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know where to start.

Creativity.question: You have to plan a special event or project.
options: A: I rely on other people’s ideas and don’t contribute my own.
B: I come up with a unique, well-thought-out plan.
C: I rush through the planning process and settle for basic ideas.
D: I forget about the details and hope it turns out okay.
E: I follow a template and don’t add any personal touch.

Creativity.question: You encounter a new opportunity that excites you.
options: A: I doubt my ability to succeed and back away.
B: I explore it and think about how I can make the most of it.
C: I wait for someone else to take the lead.
D: I feel overwhelmed and avoid the opportunity.
E: I don’t pursue it because I’m afraid of failing.

Creativity.question: You are given a problem with no clear solution.
options: A: I feel confused and don’t attempt to solve it.
B: I break down the problem and brainstorm creative solutions.
C: I try to copy someone else’s approach.
D: I avoid thinking about the problem and hope someone else solves it.
E: I solve it in a standard way without thinking of other approaches.

Creativity.question: You need to make an important decision.
options: A: I ignore my options and go with the easiest choice.
B: I consider various solutions and choose the one that feels best.
C: I overthink and feel unsure of what to do.
D: I ask others to make the decision for me.
E: I avoid making the decision and leave it to chance.

Creativity.question: You need to come up with an idea for a creative project.
options: A: I struggle to think of anything and give up.
B: I brainstorm and explore various unique ideas.
C: I stick to basic, conventional ideas.
D: I copy someone else’s idea because it’s easier.
E: I avoid thinking about it because I don’t know where to start.

TimeManagement.question: You have a homework deadline coming up.
options: A: I forget about the deadline.
B: I create a schedule to finish on time.
C: I leave it to the last minute.
D: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know where to begin.
E: I plan to start but often procrastinate.

TimeManagement.question: You want to balance school and hobbies.
options: A: I feel I have too much to do.
B: I try to fit everything in but get stressed.
C: I set aside time for both and stick to it.
D: I don’t manage my time at all.
E: I often choose fun over responsibilities.

TimeManagement.question: You’re planning for a weekend event.
options: A: I think about it but don’t write anything down.
B: I rush to get things done at the last moment.
C: I make a plan and prepare in advance.
D: I feel stressed and disorganized.
E: I don’t care to plan.

TimeManagement.question: You’re preparing for exams.
options: A: I don’t take exams seriously.
B: I feel overwhelmed and don’t study at all.
C: I study a bit but don’t stick to a schedule.
D: I create a study plan and follow it.
E: I start studying too late and feel unprepared.

TimeManagement.question: You want to make time for friends.
options: A: I schedule hangouts and make it a priority.
B: I want to see them but often forget.
C: I don’t reach out because I’m busy with other things.
D: I think friendship isn’t important.
E: I feel too busy to spend time with friends.

TimeManagement.question: You have a long-term project with multiple deadlines.
options: A: I leave everything until the last minute.
B: I create a schedule and set deadlines for each part.
C: I get stressed and don’t know where to start.
D: I focus on other tasks and forget about the project.
E: I try to start but don’t plan properly.

TimeManagement.question: You want to finish a book but have limited time.
options: A: I make time to read a little each day.
B: I read it whenever I feel like it.
C: I set a goal to finish it but get distracted.
D: I try to read the whole book at once.
E: I don’t make time to read at all.

TimeManagement.question: You have a busy week ahead with lots of tasks.
options: A: I try to handle tasks as they come up.
B: I create a to-do list and prioritize my tasks.
C: I feel overwhelmed and don’t know where to begin.
D: I focus on tasks that I enjoy and ignore the rest.
E: I wait for the weekend to catch up on everything.

TimeManagement.question: You want to manage your time better in a group project.
options: A: I wait for someone else to take charge of organizing.
B: I plan and communicate with the team about tasks and deadlines.
C: I struggle to keep track of tasks and fall behind.
D: I leave the planning to others and just follow along.
E: I take on all tasks by myself to avoid delays.

TimeManagement.question: You’re balancing school and part-time work.
options: A: I keep track of my responsibilities and plan my days carefully.
B: I find it hard to balance and end up missing deadlines.
C: I prioritize work over school and feel stressed about it.
D: I avoid organizing and hope it all works out.
E: I manage but feel overwhelmed most of the time.

TimeManagement.question: You want to improve your study habits.
options: A: I study in bursts but don’t have a set schedule.
B: I plan study sessions in advance and stick to the schedule.
C: I cram the night before and feel unprepared.
D: I study when I feel like it, without consistency.
E: I don’t prioritize studying and do it when I have free time.

TimeManagement.question: You need to make time for self-care.
options: A: I forget about self-care and get caught up in other tasks.
B: I schedule time for self-care and stick to it.
C: I prioritize other things and neglect self-care.
D: I try to make time but often skip it.
E: I think about it but don’t take action.

TimeManagement.question: You need to plan your day effectively.
options: A: I plan everything down to the minute and stick to it.
B: I make a general plan but leave room for flexibility.
C: I don’t plan and just go with the flow.
D: I try to plan but often forget or change my schedule.
E: I don’t see the point in planning my day.

TimeManagement.question: You’re attending multiple social events in one weekend.
options: A: I plan and balance my time to attend all events.
B: I get overwhelmed and end up missing some events.
C: I only attend the events I feel like going to.
D: I avoid attending events because I don’t have enough time.
E: I try to squeeze everything in and feel rushed.

TimeManagement.question: You have a new project with a tight deadline.
options: A: I wait until the deadline approaches and panic.
B: I break the project into tasks and prioritize them.
C: I work on it when I feel like it and leave it last minute.
D: I get stressed and don’t make progress.
E: I avoid thinking about the deadline and hope it works out.

Optimism.question: You face a challenge at school.
options: A: I think it’s too hard and give up.
B: I believe I can overcome it with some effort.
C: I feel defeated and doubt I can succeed.
D: I hope things will improve without effort.
E: I just ignore the problem.

Optimism.question: You feel down about something.
options: A: I think things will never get better.
B: I try to find a way to feel better.
C: I believe things will improve soon.
D: I focus on the negative and feel hopeless.
E: I ignore my feelings and keep going.

Optimism.question: You face a tough situation at home.
options: A: I believe things will get worse.
B: I find ways to stay positive.
C: I feel like I can’t do anything to fix it.
D: I wait for things to get better by themselves.
E: I try to make the best of it.

Optimism.question: You think about your future.
options: A: I feel uncertain and unsure.
B: I believe good things will happen.
C: I am excited but worry about the challenges.
D: I’m not hopeful about my future.
E: I think about the difficulties ahead.

Optimism.question: You’re looking forward to a new opportunity.
options: A: I’m excited and confident.
B: I feel unsure but hopeful.
C: I’m not sure if it will work out.
D: I’m doubtful and think it might not succeed.
E: I’m afraid of failing.

Optimism.question: You receive a bad grade on a test.
options: A: I feel like I’ll never improve.
B: I believe I can study harder and do better next time.
C: I feel defeated and don’t know where to start.
D: I think the test was unfair and give up.
E: I don’t care and move on without worrying.

Optimism.question: You have to give a presentation in front of your class.
options: A: I’m terrified and think I’ll fail.
B: I believe I’ll do well and just need to prepare.
C: I’m nervous, but I try to stay positive.
D: I feel like it’s going to be terrible, but I’ll get through it.
E: I avoid thinking about it and hope it works out.

Optimism.question: You’ve just been given an extra assignment with a tight deadline.
options: A: I’m stressed and think I won’t finish it on time.
B: I believe I can manage if I organize my time.
C: I feel overwhelmed and doubt my ability to get it done.
D: I’m confident I’ll get it done, even if it’s tough.
E: I avoid thinking about the deadline and hope it’ll be okay.

Optimism.question: You’re facing a personal setback.
options: A: I think everything is falling apart and won’t get better.
B: I believe I can learn from this and improve.
C: I feel helpless and wonder if things will ever change.
D: I’m upset, but I know I can handle it eventually.
E: I try to ignore it and hope it works out by itself.

Optimism.question: You’re about to start a new project with a tight timeline.
options: A: I don’t think I’ll be able to do it on time.
B: I’m excited and ready to take on the challenge.
C: I’m unsure if I can make it, but I’ll try my best.
D: I think it’s going to be difficult, but I’ll manage.
E: I’m afraid I won’t succeed and want to avoid it.

Optimism.question: You’re experiencing a lot of stress from schoolwork.
options: A: I don’t think things will ever calm down.
B: I know this stress will pass, and I can manage it.
C: I’m feeling overwhelmed but will get through it.
D: I don’t know how to handle it, and it feels too much.
E: I ignore the stress and keep pushing through.

Optimism.question: You’re trying to work on a creative project.
options: A: I don’t think I’m good enough to make it work.
B: I’m confident that my creativity will come through.
C: I’m unsure but will keep trying until it feels right.
D: I feel stuck, but I know I’ll eventually come up with something.
E: I worry that it won’t turn out well, so I avoid it.

Optimism.question: You’re moving to a new city.
options: A: I’m scared and don’t think I’ll fit in.
B: I’m excited to experience a new place and meet new people.
C: I’m nervous, but I’m looking forward to the new adventure.
D: I’m unsure about how things will go, but I’ll adjust.
E: I worry it’ll be hard and don’t want to think about it.

Optimism.question: You have to make an important decision for your future.
options: A: I don’t think I can make the right choice.
B: I believe I can make the right decision with enough thought.
C: I’m unsure, but I will figure it out in time.
D: I think it’s a big decision, but I can handle it.
E: I avoid thinking about it because I’m too uncertain.

Optimism.question: You face a tough challenge with a friend.
options: A: I think it will be hard to fix things between us.
B: I believe we can work things out and come to a solution.
C: I feel like we’re too different to resolve this.
D: I hope things will just improve without any effort.
E: I avoid thinking about it and hope it gets better on its own.
